title: NIFI-9228 Refactor tests using TemporaryKeyStoreBuilder
body:
#### Description of PR

NIFI-9228 Removes additional keystore and truststore files from version control, replacing references with a new `TemporaryKeyStoreBuilder` class.  Updates include refactoring tests for `SslContextFactory` and `StandardTlsConfiguration` in `nifi-security-utils`.

The new `TemporaryKeyStoreBuilder` replaces references to `KeyStoreUtils.createKeyStoreAndGetX509Certificate()`, encapsulating `File.deleteOnExit()` as part of the build process.

Additional changes include removing the unused `hadoop-minikdc` test dependency from `nifi-security-utils`. This change involved replacing `org.apache.kerby.util.Hex` with the Bouncy Castle `Hex` utility class.

In order to streamline the review of the contribution we ask you
to ensure the following steps have been taken:

### For all changes:
- [X] Is there a JIRA ticket associated with this PR? Is it referenced 
     in the commit message?

- [X] Does your PR title start with **NIFI-XXXX** where XXXX is the JIRA number you are trying to resolve? Pay particular attention to the hyphen "-" character.

- [X] Has your PR been rebased against the latest commit within the target branch (typically `main`)?

- [X] Is your initial contribution a single, squashed commit? _Additional commits in response to PR reviewer feedback should be made on this branch and pushed to allow change tracking. Do not `squash` or use `--force` when pushing to allow for clean monitoring of changes._

### For code changes:
- [ ] Have you ensured that the full suite of tests is executed via `mvn -Pcontrib-check clean install` at the root `nifi` folder?
- [X] Have you written or updated unit tests to verify your changes?
- [X] Have you verified that the full build is successful on JDK 8?
- [ ] Have you verified that the full build is successful on JDK 11?
- [ ] If adding new dependencies to the code, are these dependencies licensed in a way that is compatible for inclusion under [ASF 2.0](http://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-a)? 
- [ ] If applicable, have you updated the `LICENSE` file, including the main `LICENSE` file under `nifi-assembly`?
- [ ] If applicable, have you updated the `NOTICE` file, including the main `NOTICE` file found under `nifi-assembly`?

### For documentation related changes:

### Note:

title: NIFI-9228 Refactor tests to use generated KeyStores
body:
#### Description of PR

NIFI-9228 Refactors multiple unit tests and integration tests to use `KeyStoreUtils` to generate temporary KeyStore and TrustStore files in order to support TLS communication. This approach removes the need for files in the repository with certificate expiration dates leading to current and future build failures.

Changes include removing JKS and PKCS12 test files from multiple modules, as well as removing multiple unnecessary Logback test configuration files.  Additional adjustments include removing logging from some impacted unit tests, and removing several integration tests that relied on hard-coded KeyStores.

In order to streamline the review of the contribution we ask you

title: NIFI-9208 Adding Flow Resource Provider Service
body:
[NIFI-9208](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-9208)

This is my proposal to extend the capability of NiFi to gather necessary resources by itself. Based on the recently added "NAR Provider" functionality, this aims to be a more generalised solution for the issue: by adding providers, NiFi will be capable to collect driver jars and other necessary files from different sources (right now: from HDFS). To achieve this, I extracted the "NAR Provider" and refactored the code to be more configurable. This also involves the "NAR Provider" itself, which is now depending on the new version. For compatibility reasons, some of the interface and the HDFS implementation remained there, but they are backed by the Flow Resource Processor class family. Thank you for taking the time to take a look on this proposal, any opinion is welcomed!

title: NIFI-9174: Adding AWS SecretsManager ParamValueProvider for Stateless
body:
#### Description of PR

_Adds a ParameterValueProvider using AWS SecretsManager_

To test:

```
aws secretsmanager create-secret --name "Context" --secret-string '{ "Param": "value" }'
```

Create a flow with a Parameter Context named "Context" and a Parameter named "Param".  The flow could demonstrate the value by logging the parameter via `LogAttribute`.  Save the flow definition and launch stateless using the following configuration:

```
nifi.stateless.parameter.provider.AWSSecretsManager.name=AWS Secrets Manager Provider
nifi.stateless.parameter.provider.AWSSecretsManager.type=org.apache.nifi.stateless.parameter.AwsSecretsManagerParameterValueProvider
nifi.stateless.parameter.provider.AWSSecretsManager.properties.aws-credentials-file=./conf/bootstrap-aws.conf
```

title: NIFI-9213 Upgrade Dependency Check Plugin to 6.3.1
body:
#### Description of PR

NIFI-9213 Upgrades the Maven OWASP Dependency Check Plugin from 6.1.5 to 6.3.1 and updates the suppression configuration to exclude several false positives. Updates support optional generation of the OWASP Dependency-Check Report, which provides details on dependencies with associated vulnerabilities. Suppression updates include the following:

- Suppressed false positive for ftpserver-core
- Suppressed false positive for com.metamx:http-client
- Suppressed false positive for Jetty servlet-api
- Suppressed false positive for Testcontainers MySQL
- Suppressed false positive for vorbis-java-tika

title: NIFI-9003: Adding ParameterProviders to NiFi
body:
#### Implements ParameterProviders

This PR implements the back-end functionality described in the [Parameter Providers Feature Proposal](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/NIFI/Parameter+Providers%3A+Fetching+Parameters+from+External+Sources).  A NiFi CLI script has been added to the [NIFI-9003 JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-9003) for running a basic test of the functionality.

Included features:
- Added `ParameterProvider` interface to framework
- Added `EnvironmentVariableParameterProvider` to `nifi-standard-nar`
- Added CLI commands for interacting with parameter providers
- UI search bar and documentation integration for parameter providers

Not included:
- UI implementation of creating/displaying/updating/deleting parameter providers, or integrating them into parameter contexts
- Automatic periodic fetch-and-apply

title: NIFI-9184 Refactor shared methods in Sensitive Property Providers
body:
#### Description of PR

NIFI-9184 Refactors shared methods for Base64 encoding and client status handling in the following Sensitive Property Providers:

- AWS KMS
- Azure Key Vault Key
- GCP KMS

Changes include abstracting client initialization to a `ClientProvider` interface with a shared method for reading client properties from a referenced configuration file. Abstracting client initialization provided the opportunity to introduced unit tests for AWS KMS and Azure Key Vault Key providers. the GCP `KeyManagementServiceClient` does not implement an interface and has methods marked as `final`, which does not lend itself to mocked unit testing.

The client initialization approach in `BoostrapPropertiesClientProvider` checks for the presence of the specified path property as well as the existence of the referenced properties file. As multiple Sensitive Property Provider implementations are not designed to be used together, commenting out the referenced configuration file properties in the default `bootstrap.conf` provides a better approach to the default system configuration.

title: NIFI-8749 Remove implicit time zone conversion to GMT
body:
#### Description of PR

NIFI-8749 Removes implicit time zone conversion to GMT when parsing dates and times from strings to objects. This addresses a latent issue in `DataTypeUtils.getDateFormat()` leading to unexpected behavior in record-oriented components and other date parsing capabilities.

This pull request includes the same commit as #5305 with additional changes to `TestRecordPath` using an static value for `user.timezone`. Using a static `user.timezone` value in `TestRecordPath` avoids localized build failures where the system time zone causes test failures in time zone conversion. This addresses the issue described in NIFI-9187.

Removing the implicit conversion to GMT restores standard behavior where NiFi handles date parsing according to the system default time zone. This has no impact when parsing timestamps containing an explicit time zone, but addresses issues in components such as `PutDatabaseRecord` when parsing timestamps without a time zone indicator in the string.

The current Expression Language Guide indicates that both the `format` and `toDate` functions default to the local time zone when the second argument is not specified. The Record Path Guide previously indicated a default time zone of GMT for the `toDate` function, reflecting the actual behavior when support for a time zone argument was introduced. Recent updates to PutDatabaseRecord in NIFI-8223, released in NiFi 1.13.0, surfaced this implicit conversion issue when handling timestamp inputs from Record Readers.

Changes include replacing the GMT Time Zone in `DataTypeUtils.getDateFormat()` with the explicit default of `TimeZone.getDefault()`. Additional updates include unit test adjustments in order to conform expected values to meet the corrected behavior.

title: NIFI-9183: Add a command-line option to save status history
body:
<!--
  Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one or more
  contributor license agreements.  See the NOTICE file distributed with

  See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
  limitations under the License.
-->
Thank you for submitting a contribution to Apache NiFi.

Please provide a short description of the PR here:

#### Description of PR

Added command-line option to save status history in JSON.

**Details**

When you run _nifi.sh_ with a command line option, the _RunNiFi_ class parses the options, creates a _NiFi_ server instance, and sends a request to the _BootstrapListener_ on the server. Objects from _nifi-core_ can be injected by spring web context. Since only a single _NiFiServer_ instance can be accessed in _BootstrapListener_, I extended it with a new method that returns the status history.

- Outsourced _StatusHistoryRepository_ creation to a factory bean from _FlowController_ in order to use it in _nifi-runtime_.
- The _NiFiServer_ interface has been extended with the _String getNodeStatusHistoryJson(final int days);_ method. (Returns a string in order to avoid additional dependencies in nifi-bootstrap. Dependencies in nifi-runtime affect nifi-bootstrap as well, and they must be added to assembly/common.xml filters.)
- Extended _RunNiFi_ and _nifi.sh_ with the new status-history option.
- The StatusHistoryRepository gets injected into JettyServer which can be accessed by NiFiBootstrap.

**Still under consideration or work in progress:**

- NiFiServer: default vs not default method?
- Extend admin guide

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-9183

title: NIFI-9049 Replace localStorage with sessionStorage for Bearer Token
body:
#### Description of PR

NIFI-9049 Replaces browser-based persistence of JSON Web Tokens in `localStorage` with a new `nf.AuthorizationStorage` component based on `sessionStorage`.

The current implementation relies on persisting an expiration timestamp along with the JSON Web Token, but the `localStorage` entry remains in the browser across multiple tabs and browser restarts. With the introduction of HTTP Session Cookies in #4988, this can result in the browser retaining the token in `localStorage` after the browser has removed the HTTP Session Cookie. This mismatch of persistence lifespan results in NiFi allowing access to the user interface, but denying access when open custom UI extensions of viewing provenance data content. Those user interface requests require the presence of the HTTP Session Cookie for access.

Changing the persistent storage approach ensures that both the HTTP Session Cookie and the `sessionStorage` contents will be removed when restarting the browser.

Changes in this Pull Request also include checking for the existence of the `Authorization` header in `AccessResource.getAccessStatus()`, and instructing the browser to remove the Session Cookie when the `Authorization` header is missing. Updating the `nf-canvas.js` loading process to call `getAccessStatus()` ensures that both the HTTP Session Cookie and the JSON Web Token from `sessionStorage` are present. This addresses scenarios where the browser may have the Session Cookie, but not have the token, which then redirects the browser to the login screen.

In order to streamline the review of the contribution we ask you

title: NIFI-9082 Add nifi.zookeeper.jute.maxbuffer property
body:
#### Description of PR

NIFI-9082 Adds `nifi.zookeeper.jute.maxbuffer` as a configurable setting in `nifi.properties` for `ZooKeeperStateProvider` and ZooKeeper clustering. The default value is just under 1 MB based on the default value of `1048575` bytes described in the [ZooKeeper Administrator's Guide](https://zookeeper.apache.org/doc/r3.5.9/zookeeperAdmin.html#Unsafe+Options). This default value aligns with the current hard-coded data size limit of 1 MB defined in `ZooKeeperStateProvider`.

Although the default value applies to the majority of use cases, and increasing the value can have other performance impacts, ZooKeeper supports larger values. Introducing this configurable property in NiFi supports optional configuration of a larger buffer in conjunction with changing the property on ZooKeeper servers.

title: NIFI-9060 Improve HTTP Cookie Path Handling
body:
#### Description of PR

NIFI-9060 Refactors HTTP cookie processing to improve integration when running NiFi behind a reverse proxy server. The `nifi.web.proxy.context.path` property provides the option for NiFi to accept forwarded context paths using HTTP headers such as `X-ProxyContextPath`. Instead of using the hard-coded root path `/` for HTTP cookies, the new `ApplicationCookieService` interface and implementation support setting the path based on the proxy header when provided.

Additional changes include adjusting the prefix of the `Authorization-Bearer` cookie name from `__Host-` to `__Secure-`.  The [__Host-](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-rfc6265bis#section-4.1.3.2) prefix requires the cookie `Path` property set to `/`, necessitating the change to [__Secure-](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-rfc6265bis#section-4.1.3.1) in order to support different path values.  The `__Secure-` prefix works in conjunction with the `Secure` property to ensure that the client will only send the cookie over HTTPS.

Several login and logout JavaScript functions included hard-coded `window.location` redirects to `/nifi`, which did not function correctly when running behind a reverse proxy server.  Other functions use the `../nifi/` path, which works in both reverse proxy and standard configurations, and also avoids unnecessary redirects from `/nifi` to `/nifi/`.

In order to streamline the review of the contribution we ask you

#### Description of PR

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-9072

title: NIFI-9067 Upgraded JAXB Runtime from 2.3.0 to 2.3.5
body:
#### Description of PR

NIFI-9067 Upgrades JAXB Runtime dependencies from 2.3.0 to 2.3.5 and also upgrades the JAXB API dependency from 2.3.0 to 2.3.3. This update resolves the following warning when running NiFi, NiFi Stateless, NiFi Toolkit, or MiNiFi on Java 11:

```
Illegal reflective access by com.sun.xml.bind.v2.runtime.reflect.opt.Injector
```
Upgrading versions also involves migrating to the currently maintained Maven packages. The JAXB API Maven coordinates are now `jakarta.xml.bind:jakarta.xml.bind-api` instead of `javax.xml.bind:jaxb-api`. The JAXB implementation is now packaged as `org.glassfish.jaxb:jaxb-runtime`. The JAXB API package has a transitive dependency on `jakarta.activation-api`, so explicit declaration in multiple locations is no longer necessary. Updates include indicating the new Maven coordinates and associated licenses in the NiFi assembly notices.

In order to streamline the review of the contribution we ask you
to ensure the following steps have been taken:

title: NIFI-9055 Added handling for 0- read range to FetchS3Object
body:
#### Description of PR

This fixes a bug in FetchS3Object preventing reading zero byte objects. S3 uses the HTTP Range header for specifying byte ranges. Zero length content doesn't have a satisfiable byte range so we shouldn't call GetObjectRequest#setRange(0) unnecessarily when neither Range Start nor Range Length are given.

title: NIFI-9040 Add GitHub Workflow for System Tests
body:
#### Description of PR

NIFI-9040 Adds a GitHub Workflow to run integration tests in the `nifi-system-test-suite` module on a daily schedule. The workflow configuration runs on Ubuntu Java 11 and MacOS Java 8. The current integration tests fail on Windows, so separate work is necessary to evaluate potential changes for the Windows platform.

Running the integration tests on a daily basis using the default `main` branch provides additional automated verification without burdening the existing pull request workflow.

In order to optimize the job and avoid running unnecessary tests, the workflow runs two Maven commands. The first command builds the modules required for `nifi-system-test-suite`:

`mvn -V -nsu -ntp -ff install -D skipTests -am -pl nifi-system-tests/nifi-system-test-suite`

The second command runs the integration tests:

`mvn -V -nsu -ntp -ff package verify -P integration-tests -pl nifi-system-tests/nifi-system-test-suite`

The following GitHub Actions link provides an example workflow run:

https://github.com/exceptionfactory/nifi/actions/runs/1140278748

In order to streamline the review of the contribution we ask you

Thank you for submitting a contribution to Apache NiFi.

Please provide a short description of the PR here:

#### Description of PR

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-8917

Allows project builds to exclude (optionally) minifi, nifi-registry and/or nifi-toolkit module(s) from the build. This is done by using a maven property option: -DexcludeMinifi, -DexcludeNiFiRegistry and/or -DexcludeNiFiToolkit. The absence of the property will result in default behavior, i.e. the module will be included in the build.
No unit tests are included, but separate builds were run using each of the three properties or combinations of them to verify expected behavior.

This PR was re-submitted because the linkage between JIRA and the original PR was broken.
